script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David. Happy to be here!

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, I have to start with a mystery that’s been on my mind. In Moses 1, God calls Moses His son and reveals His glory, but just moments later, Satan shows up and tries to deceive him. Why would Satan dare to challenge someone who just saw God face-to-face? And what does this showdown reveal about our own divine identity?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, that’s a fantastic question, and it cuts to the heart of a profound spiritual pattern. Satan’s timing isn’t random—he strikes right after Moses’s divine encounter because he knows that identity is everything. If he can shake Moses’s understanding of who he is as a son of God, he can derail his mission. Let’s unpack this because there’s a hidden key here that connects to each of us.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wait, I’m intrigued. So you’re saying this isn’t just a personal attack on Moses—it’s a universal tactic? How do we see this from different perspectives, like Moses’s view versus ours today?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly, Sarah. From Moses’s perspective in Moses 1:4 and 6, God affirms, ‘Thou art my son,’ and ‘thou art in the similitude of mine Only Begotten.’ That’s a direct, personal revelation of identity. But Satan counters in verse 12 with, ‘Moses, son of man, worship me,’ trying to downgrade his divine heritage. Now, fast forward to our modern view—President Russell M. Nelson has taught that the first thing God wants us to know is our true identity as His children, as he said in ‘Choices for Eternity.’ Satan’s tactic hasn’t changed; he still tries to confuse us about who we are.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s fascinating, but how does this play out across different dispensations? Is this pattern of identity and deception something we see repeatedly in scripture?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Absolutely, Sarah. Let’s trace this theme of divine identity versus deception across time. Start with Moses in Exodus, where he’s called to deliver Israel but doubts himself—Satan’s whispers of inadequacy are implied there. Then look at Christ in Matthew 4:1-11, tempted by Satan in the wilderness right after His baptism, with taunts questioning, ‘If thou be the Son of God.’ Move to Joseph Smith in the First Vision, where thick darkness precedes the light of God’s presence. And today, we face the same battle over identity with cultural voices challenging our divine worth.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I’m seeing it now—a consistent pattern of attack right at the moment of divine revelation. But what’s the deeper significance? Why is identity the battleground across all these eras?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here’s where it gets powerful, Sarah. Identity is the foundation of purpose. In Abraham 3:22-23, we learn that we were among the ‘noble and great ones’ chosen before the world was. If we forget that, we lose sight of our mission, just as Moses could have. Satan knows that if he can make us question our divine DNA, he can stop God’s work, which, as Moses 1:39 states, is ‘to bring to pass the immortality and eternal life of man.’

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a stunning connection. Hold that thought—I want to dive into some historical context. What do we know about the cultural or religious environment Moses was in that might have made Satan’s attack even more potent?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Great question, Sarah. Moses, having grown up in Pharaoh’s court, was surrounded by Egyptian polytheism, where gods were tied to nature and power, not personal relationships. Satan’s demand to be worshipped in Moses 1:12 would have echoed the deification of rulers Moses knew well—think of Pharaoh as a ‘living god.’ This cultural backdrop made Satan’s counterfeit offer tempting, but it also made God’s declaration of sonship revolutionary, collapsing the distance between man and deity in a way Egyptian theology couldn’t fathom.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a time-collapse moment for me—imagining Moses unlearning everything he knew about divinity. What’s another historical layer that deepens this story?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Let’s look at the ancient Near Eastern concept of sonship. In many cultures, being called a ‘son’ of a king or god meant adoption into a covenant relationship with specific duties. When God calls Moses ‘my son’ in Moses 1:4, it’s not just affectionate—it’s a covenantal claim, binding Moses to God’s work. Satan’s attempt to redefine him as a mere ‘son of man’ is a direct assault on that covenant bond, a tactic we see mirrored in later Israelite struggles with idolatry.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I never saw that covenant angle before. Let’s circle back to the mystery we started with—why Satan dares to challenge Moses right after his vision, and what that reveals about our identity. What’s the resolution here?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, the resolution is both tactical and theological. Satan dares to challenge Moses because he knows spiritual highs are followed by vulnerability—think of Elijah after Mount Carmel or Christ after fasting. But the deeper reveal is in Moses’s response in verse 13: ‘Who art thou? For behold, I am a son of God, in the similitude of his Only Begotten.’ That declaration of identity, rooted in God’s revelation, is what gives Moses power to resist. It shows us that knowing we are children of God is our ultimate defense against deception.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s remarkable. So, our identity isn’t just a feel-good truth—it’s a shield. Let’s explore some hidden connections across scriptures. Are there other places where this identity theme ties directly to resisting evil?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Definitely. Look at Abraham 3:25, where God says of the premortal spirits, ‘We will prove them herewith, to see if they will do all things whatsoever the Lord their God shall command them.’ Our identity as God’s children comes with a purpose to be proven, just as Moses was. Then connect that to Doctrine and Covenants 76:24, where we’re called ‘begotten sons and daughters unto God’ through Christ—a reminder of our divine lineage even in mortality. And notice in 1 John 3:1-2, John marvels that ‘we should be called the sons of God,’ linking identity to our future exaltation.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I’m blown away by how those verses weave together a web of identity across time. It’s like a divine thread from premortality to eternity. How does this tie into the Plan of Salvation?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, it’s at the core. The Plan of Salvation, as outlined in Abraham 3:24-26, is about creating an earth where we can be proven and, through Christ, achieve eternal life. Our identity as children of God is what makes us candidates for that plan—God’s work and glory in Moses 1:39 hinges on us embracing that identity. Without it, we can’t fully participate in the covenants that lead to exaltation.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a powerful lens. Let’s shift to another connection. How does this identity theme link to Christ specifically, especially in these chapters?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here’s a beautiful cross-reference, Sarah. In Moses 1:6, God tells Moses, ‘thou art in the similitude of mine Only Begotten; and mine Only Begotten is and shall be the Savior.’ That ties Moses’s identity directly to Christ’s role. Then in Abraham 3:27, Christ volunteers as the one to fulfill the Father’s plan, saying, ‘Here am I, send me.’ Our divine identity is mirrored in Christ’s willingness to redeem us—He’s the ultimate example of living out divine sonship.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love how that centers everything on the Savior. It’s like our identity as children of God is only fully realized through Him. Are there other subtle connections most people might miss?

script.speaker: David
script.text: One more that’s often overlooked, Sarah. In Moses 1:30, Moses asks, ‘Tell me, I pray thee, why these things are so, and by what thou madest them?’ God’s response in verse 32, ‘by the word of my power, have I created them,’ points to Christ as the Word, as in John 1:1-3, where ‘all things were made by him.’ So, Moses’s vision of creation is inherently Christ-centered, reinforcing that our identity and purpose are tied to the Savior’s creative and redemptive power.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a mind-blowing link—I never connected those dots before. Let’s bring this into our lives today. How does understanding our identity as children of God change the way we face modern challenges or temptations?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, it transforms everything. When we internalize that we are children of God, as President Nelson emphasized in ‘Choices for Eternity,’ it shifts our decision-making. Facing temptation, we can echo Moses in Moses 1:13 and say, ‘I am a son or daughter of God,’ refusing to settle for lesser identities. It gives us strength to reject Satan’s counterfeits—whether that’s societal pressure, self-doubt, or sin—because we know our worth and purpose.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s so practical. I can see how remembering my divine identity could help in moments of insecurity or tough choices. What’s another modern application from this?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Another angle is how we treat others. If we truly see everyone as children of God, as Moses 1:4 teaches, it changes our interactions. It’s harder to judge or belittle when we recognize the divine in each person, aligning with modern prophetic teachings to love and lift others. It also motivates us to share the gospel, knowing we’re helping others discover their eternal identity.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a beautiful takeaway. Before we wrap up, David, what’s one final thought or invitation you’d leave with our listeners based on these incredible discoveries?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, I’d invite everyone to take a moment this week to reflect on Moses 1:4 and Abraham 3:22-23, and write down what it means to you to be a child of God. Let that identity sink deep into your heart. Then, when challenges come, recall Moses’s strength and stand firm in who you are. It’s a game-changer.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that invitation, David. Thank you for uncovering these profound connections with us today. Listeners, join us next time as we continue exploring the scriptures together. Until then, keep seeking those divine insights!
